Award.AwardTitle: STTR Phase II: Advanced Hybrid Piezoelectric Energy Harvester
Award.AbstractNarration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this project is to manufacture an advanced hybrid energy harvester that can enable broad deployment of wireless sensor networks. Self-sustainable uninterrupted low-cost power supply with small size is in urgent need for internet of things, portable electric devices, wireless sensor networks, infrastructure health monitoring, active control, and battleground soldier support. Scavenging ambient energy from environment to power these devices can eliminate the cost of replacing batteries, particularly in remote environment. The hybrid energy harvesters developed in this project will significantly improve the power output and response dynamic frequency, therefore provide sufficient power to many such devices. The high power density will also enable more frequent data acquisition and transmission of such sensor networks, and promote more ubiquitous deployment of advanced sensor networks. The automatic manufacturing process will enable their adoption by various customers including internet of things.

This Small Business Technology Transfer Research (STTR) Phase 2 project will develop manufacturing processes for advanced hybrid energy harvesters. Although piezoelectric energy harvesters have found broad applications, their power density and mechanical-electrical conversion efficiency are still low, with values at microwatts to milliwatt and <10%, respectively since they primarily operate at the d31 mode of the piezoelectric transducer and the mechanical impedance mismatch between the vibration source and the harvesting device. The Phase I project successfully demonstrated that the advanced hybrid energy harvesting device can provide significantly higher power density at > 100 mW and conversion efficiency at > 40% by using the more efficient d33 piezoelectric mode and with reduced stiffness in a curved structure that can efficiently transfer the energy from the vibration source to the active piezoelectric materials. The Phase II project will be focused on developing low-cost innovative automatic manufacturing process to enable their practical applications in commercial and industrial market.

ProgramReference.Text: REU SUPP-Res Exp for Ugrd Supp

POR.DRECONTENT:
Advanced hybrid energy harvester with superior electrical energy output can enable broad deployment of wireless sensor networks. Self-sustainable uninterrupted low-cost power supply with small size is in urgent need for internet of things, portable electric devices, wireless sensor networks, infrastructure health monitoring, active control, and battleground soldier support. Scavenging ambient energy from environment to power these devices can eliminate the cost of replacing batteries, particularly in remote environment.

National Institute of Aerospace and PolyK Technologies developed the advanced hybrid piezoelectric energy harvesting devices by using an interdisciplinary approach combining high performance materials and smart mechanical and electrical design. The novel piezoelectric device uses the d33 mode, rather than the common d31 mode, to generate electrical power as d33 is usually 100% higher than d31. It also utilizes a curved stack design to effectively reduce the stiffness and resonance frequency of the piezoelectric materials such that the external vibration can be effectively transferred to the active piezo stacks. Therefore, these devices can generate significantly more electrical energy and higher efficiency than competing technology. It was selected as one of the 2016 R&D 100 Technology Award Finalists.

While the award-winning hybrid energy harvesters can generate sigificant amount of electricla power, the labor-intensive fabricationi process seriously limit their practical applications. This STTR Phase II project successfully developed a low-cost manufacturing process than can significantly reduce the cost of the advanced energy harvesting devices, and improve the reproducibility. Preliminar test results demonstrate that they can generate sufficient energy to charge smartphone and from motor vibrations to power health monitoring sensors fro motor bearings.


Last Modified: 09/03/2019
Modified by: Shihai Zhang

Image
  • Advanced piezoelectric energy harvesting can generate significant amount of electrical energy from vibration with innovative device design and low-cost manufacturing process. They can be used to provide self-sustainable electrical power in wireless sensor systems.
    PolyK Technology
    Copyrighted
    Shihai Zhang
    Advanced Piezoelectric Energy Harvesting Devices
